meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Monday 2026-01-26 in Rockford, MI: very cold but essentially no accumulating snow is forecast (0 inches). The main travel concern is NOT snow depth—it's a brief window of light freezing rain around midnight, followed by multiple overnight hours with extremely poor/near-zero visibility indicated in the hourly data (likely fog/low stratus). Winds increase through the day (gusts ~20–25 mph), producing dangerous wind chills (around -5°F at times), but wind alone is unlikely to trigger a closure in Michigan. Net: low snow-day likelihood from snowfall; the only plausible disruption scenario would be patchy overnight icing plus dense fog reducing morning road visibility.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, mostly dry post-system day: light snow/freezing precip ends overnight, then a stable, cold, overcast day with modest wind (10–15 mph). Roads typically improve by the morning commute if pretreatment/plowing occurred the prior day.

Trace-to-very-light freezing drizzle/freezing rain at/near midnight with temperatures in the low teens (°F), followed by no additional precip. Main risk is isolated slick spots (bridges/ramps/untreated secondary roads) rather than widespread impassability.

Low-visibility fog/low stratus signal (multiple hours showing near-zero visibility in the feed) without ongoing snowfall. This can slow buses on rural roads but rarely triggers full closure unless paired with icing or heavy snow.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly supports persistent snowpack/icy shoulders and frequent below-freezing highs. A day with highs in the mid-teens (°F) and no accumulating snow is operationally normal; closures are more often driven by heavy snow rates, widespread glaze ice, or extreme wind chills rather than cold alone.
unusual_factors: Overnight 'light freezing rain' indicated around 12:00 AM (very small QPF ~0.01 mm) creates a non-zero black-ice risk on untreated surfaces.
Forecast feed shows several early-morning hours with very low/zero visibility; if this reflects dense fog/low stratus rather than a data artifact, it can increase transportation risk.
Residual impacts from Sunday's wintry mix/light snow/freezing rain may leave patchy slick spots, especially on neighborhood roads and less-traveled rural routes.

local_microclimates: West Michigan lake-modified air can sustain low clouds and occasional flurries even when totals stay near zero; untreated backroads can remain slick longer in shaded areas.
Rockford-area rolling terrain and river valleys can promote localized fog/low visibility near dawn.
Bridges/overpasses and open country roads north and east of town tend to ice first under clear-to-overcast, sub-freezing conditions after earlier precipitation.
infrastructure_considerations: In Kent County-area operations, schools typically remain open with cold and minor snow; closures more often align with widespread glaze ice, blizzard-like visibility, or heavy snow timing during the AM commute.
After a Sunday event, road agencies often have additional staffing/plow capacity to reset main routes before Monday morning, reducing closure odds unless icing is widespread.
Bus-route sensitivity: patchy black ice + very low visibility is more likely to produce delays or selective rural-route issues than a district-wide closure.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation/terrain differences mainly affect localized icing and fog pockets rather than producing large snow-accumulation gradients; biggest practical impacts are shaded hills and bridge decks.

history.confidence_assessment: For Monday, 2026-01-26, the forecast shows essentially no accumulating snow (0 cm) and near-zero precipitation (0.01 mm), with temps ~10–17°F and winds up to ~15 mph—conditions that, by Michigan standards, rarely justify a snow day on their own. The primary watch-outs are (1) any real glaze from the overnight freezing-rain signal and (2) whether the very low visibility values are real fog/stratus at bus time. If roads are treated and visibility is not severely reduced at 6–8 AM, closure likelihood is low; at most, a modest increase in risk exists for patchy black ice on secondary roads.

safety_recommendations: Primary operational concern is refreeze/black ice: temperatures stay well below freezing all day (around 10–17°F), so any earlier light freezing rain (near 12:00 AM) can leave slick patches, especially on bridges, overpasses, and untreated side streets.

Expect low visibility pockets overnight into early morning (roughly 1 AM–8 AM shows very low vis in the data). Run buses at reduced speeds on secondary roads and increase following distance; consider adjusting routes to favor plowed/treated primary roads.
Because school starts around 7:40 AM, prioritize an early-morning road check window (about 5:30–7:00 AM) focused on hills, curves, and known shade/low-sun areas where ice persists.

Increase attention to parking lots, sidewalks, and drop-off areas: even without new snow, residual ice from prior precipitation and daytime melt/refreeze from Sunday can create slip hazards; apply salt and do spot-treatment before arrival.
For families: plan extra time, avoid sudden braking/turns, and assume some neighborhood streets may remain slick even if main roads look fine.

news.key_findings_summary: For Monday, 2026-01-26 (Rockford, MI area), I did not find a definitive Rockford Public Schools closure/delay announcement in the district’s visible news/announcements during this scan. Neighboring-district ‘domino’ signals were limited: Sparta confirmed a closure for Friday 01/23/26 (showing recent impactful conditions), but I did not capture Monday 01/26 closures for Forest Hills/Lowell/Cedar Springs in the sources retrieved here. Regional context strongly suggests winter-travel risk has been elevated recently in the Grand Rapids metro (including a major I-196 pileup and NWS ‘travel not recommended’ messaging during whiteouts). Consumers Energy’s outage page indicates very high system availability overall (not a widespread outage signal in this pass). Net: community chatter/official closure signals for Monday 01/26 appear mixed/insufficient in this snapshot—monitor Rockford Public Schools communications late Sunday night and early Monday for the decision.

clearing_timeline.estimated_road_condition_at_6_30_am: Generally passable on state trunklines and main county routes (US-131 / I-96 corridors likely OK), but expect localized icy patches from refreeze and reduced visibility in spots (fog/low vis indicated in the supplied hourly forecast). Biggest risk is neighborhood/local connectors and untreated intersections/driveways.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: Based on the supplied forecast for Monday 2026-01-26 (very cold, minimal new snow) the main operational issue is refreeze/black ice rather than accumulation. Kent County Road Commission reporting indicates substantial staffing on day shift (~90) and reduced overnight staffing (~40), consistent with ongoing overnight treatment/plowing. Expect primary routes to be in workable shape by bus time (~6:30 AM), but not uniformly ‘dry pavement’—spotty slick areas are plausible on bridges, hills, shaded roads, and neighborhood streets. A full district-wide ‘snow day’ is less likely than a normal start (or at most isolated delays), unless MI Drive shows widespread ice/snow-covered trunklines at 5–6 AM Monday.

powerGrid.overall_grid_assessment: For Rockford (Kent County) on Monday 2026-01-26, the bigger operational risk to schools is not widespread outages but extreme cold (low near 10°F, wind chills near/under 0°F around late night/early morning) and possible patchy freezing drizzle around midnight. The regional grid is under elevated stress due to extreme cold across the Midwest (MISO conservation request through early Jan 25), but current local outage counts appear low and consistent with normal operations. Snow-day likelihood from precipitation is low (near-zero snow, minimal precip), but cold-related operational disruptions (bus starts, frostbite exposure at stops, and any localized power/boiler issues) are the main concern.

critical_alerts.message: Major discrepancy: WeatherAPI forecast 'feels like' for Mon 2026-01-26 bottoms near -5.5°F, while the accessible web snapshots reviewed show 'feels like' values mostly above 0°F (roughly +1°F to +12°F). Difference exceeds 10°F.

Automatic-closure trigger check: NO reviewed source showed 'feels like' / wind chill below -20°F for Mon 2026-01-26. (WeatherAPI minimum for 2026-01-26 is about -5.5°F; some Weather.com snapshots show -20°C/-24°C for other dates/contexts, but not tied to Mon 2026-01-26 in the captured snippets.)

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: Target day is Monday, January 26, 2026 for Rockford, MI (ZIP 49341). WeatherAPI forecasts temps roughly 10–17°F with wind producing wind chills mostly near 0°F in the morning and dipping to about -5.5°F late evening (with winds increasing to ~15 mph). When cross-checking public web sources, the most accessible extracted snapshots (Weather.com, WeatherBug, Weather Underground) do not show wind chills below -20°F for Monday; however, several Weather.com pages captured by the crawler appear to mix different date contexts, and none of the extracted web snippets cleanly confirm the exact Monday 2026-01-26 hourly wind-chill curve. Because the web excerpts are not unequivocally pinned to Mon 2026-01-26, the cross-source agreement on the Monday 'feels like' is weak. Based on the WeatherAPI numbers provided, Monday looks cold but not at the automatic-closure threshold; snow on Monday is essentially nil in the API (0"), reducing the likelihood of a classic 'snow day' driven by accumulation. Main risk factors would be localized slick spots from prior freezing precip/snow and cold wind chills, but not a verified sub -20°F event.

timeline.conditions_improve: 2026-01-26 09:00–11:00 (daytime mixing and treatment improve visibility/traction; local streets/parking lots improve more slowly)

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement across experts: (a) Snow accumulation on Monday is not the issue; (b) the main hazards are patchy ice from a brief midnight freezing-precip window and possible low visibility near dawn; (c) primary roads should be generally passable by bus time with ongoing maintenance; (d) no wind-chill ≤ -20°F signal is confirmed; (e) no widespread power outage signal.
2) Disagreements: The main conflict is whether the hourly “0-mile visibility” is real widespread dense fog versus an over-aggressive model/encoding artifact. Meteorology clarified it’s more likely pockets/intermittent drops (0.5–2 mi common, near-zero in spots) rather than hours of true 0.0 mi everywhere.
3) Plow timing math: Icing/precip ends ~12:00–01:00. That leaves ~5.5 hours to 6:30 AM bus roll and ~7.7 hours to 7:40 AM start—enough for treatment on trunklines/arterials, but not enough to guarantee clean neighborhood streets given subfreezing temps.
4) Ice: Yes—non-zero risk (thin glaze/black ice). This is the biggest ‘surprise’ pathway.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel did not find confirmed Monday closures/delays in nearby districts; several show normal Monday calendars. No domino effect.
6) Power: Systemwide outages low (~155 customers) with Kent extremely low; not a driver.
7) Wind chill verification: Web verifier cannot confirm with fresh sources, but nothing supports ≤ -20°F; WeatherAPI bottoms around -5.5°F.
8) What would make me wrong: If (a) freezing fog becomes widespread with near-zero vis during 6:30–8:00 AND (b) spot checks find widespread untreated glaze on secondary roads/turnarounds, Rockford could pivot to a delay or even closure.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology (25%) + Safety (20%) + History (15%) + News (15%) + Infrastructure (10%) + Power (10%) + Web verification (5%).
- Meteorology supports low closure odds but highlights patchy ice + possible low vis.
- Safety rates the morning as high-risk operationally, but explicitly expects OPEN with a meaningful chance of DELAY rather than closure.
- History anchors closures for this pattern at ~8–15% and notes fog-alone rarely closes.
- News intel shows no neighboring-closure momentum.
- Infrastructure expects ‘generally passable’ mains by 6:30 with localized slick spots.
- Power is stable.
- Web verifier finds no extreme wind chill trigger and cannot confirm a Dense Fog Advisory.

Given Michigan thresholds: with ~0" snow and only patchy ice/fog risk, the closure probability stays low. I set 16% (slightly above the debate average 15%) to reflect the non-trivial compounded risk of patchy black ice + possible low visibility during the bus window, but without the “domino” closure signals or verified widespread dense fog, a full closure is still unlikely.

alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations; expect slick spots on neighborhood streets/parking lots and possible slower buses in low-visibility pockets.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: 2-hour DELAY due to patchy black ice and/or low visibility verified at 5:30–6:30 AM checks
alternative_scenarios.impact: Gives time for additional spot-treating, daylight improvement in visibility, and safer bus routing.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: CLOSED (full snow day) triggered by widespread glazing + widespread dense/freezing fog at bus time
alternative_scenarios.impact: Would require hazards to verify more broadly/severely than currently supported by consensus/neighboring signals.

for_schools: Plan for OPEN but be delay-ready: conduct targeted road/visibility checks 05:30–06:30 focused on bridges, hills, shaded connectors, and known fog-prone low areas/river valleys.
If visibility is consistently <0.5 mile across multiple routes OR multiple buses report widespread untreated glaze early, strongly consider a 2-hour delay rather than a full closure.
Spot-treat bus loops, drop-off zones, sidewalks, and parking lots before arrival; cold temps will prevent natural improvement.
Bus ops: reduced speeds on secondary roads; emphasize stop-arm/child visibility procedures if fog is present.
for_residents: Assume black ice on bridges/ramps and subdivision streets; slow down and increase following distance.
If fog/freezing fog develops, use low beams, avoid sudden braking, and allow extra travel time for the morning commute.
Dress for cold at bus stops; minimize time exposed and use layers/cover skin.
for_authorities: Prioritize bridge decks, ramps, and school-zone approaches for overnight/early-morning treatment; be prepared for reactive spot-treating 04:00–08:00.
If visibility rapidly deteriorates, consider targeted messaging (reduced speed, headlight use) for the 6–9 AM window.
Monitor for localized ice-jam flooding impacts only where river-adjacent roads are involved (not a broad commute driver).

keyFactors: Derived from primary analysis

positions.rationale:
As the history specialist, I’m anchoring to how districts in West Michigan typically behave in late January: cold mornings and minor snow/ice are operationally normal, and closure decisions usually require either (a) significant new snow during the commute, (b) widespread ice glazing, or (c) true whiteout/blizzard visibility. Monday’s forecast has near-zero new precip and no snow accumulation, which points strongly toward “open.”

I’m not going as low as ~5% because there are two historically meaningful ‘surprise’ ingredients: (1) the brief freezing-rain/black-ice window around midnight with temps ~10–12°F (any untreated roads stay slick), and (2) the multiple hours of near-zero visibility values (if real and coincident with 6–8 AM bus time). Those can produce occasional, low-frequency closures even without new snow totals. Net: low but non-trivial closure risk.
keyFactors: Historical analogs for West Michigan/Kent County: a cold, mostly-dry post-system Monday with modest winds is usually an “open” day; typical closure drivers are heavy snow rates, widespread glaze ice, or blizzard/whiteout visibility at bus time—not just teens/low-teens temperatures.
Forecast specifics for Mon 2026-01-26: essentially zero new accumulation (totalsnow 0 cm; total precip ~0.01 mm). That strongly suppresses the base snow-day rate.

Residual impacts from Sun 2026-01-25 wintry mix/light snow/freezing rain: even small earlier precip can leave patchy slick spots on neighborhood streets, bridge decks, and shaded hills—more consistent with delays/extra caution than full closure.

Overnight “light freezing rain” signal near 00:00 Mon + persistent subfreezing temps: raises black-ice risk, but QPF is tiny, so district-wide impassability is unlikely unless the glaze is more widespread than modeled.

Very low/zero visibility hours shown in the hourly feed: historically, dense fog/low stratus alone rarely closes schools, but fog + black ice can push marginal decisions upward (especially for bus routes on rural connectors).

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint, Monday 2026-01-26 looks more like a “caution/slow commute” day than a classic snow day: near-zero new precip and zero snow accumulation greatly reduce the chance of district-wide impassability. The credible closure pathway is a combination of (1) patchy glaze/black ice from overnight freezing drizzle/freezing rain, *plus* (2) genuinely dense fog/near-zero visibility during the bus window. If visibility rebounds and roads are treated, schools typically stay open in this part of Michigan even with cold highs in the teens. Net: low-to-moderate closure probability, with higher likelihood of localized problems, delays, or elevated accident risk than a full cancellation.
keyFactors: No meaningful new snowfall expected Monday (forecast totals ~0). Closures in West Michigan are usually driven by heavy accumulation/rates or widespread ice—not just cold.

Primary safety trigger is *ice*, not snow: a brief “light freezing rain” signal around 12:00 AM Monday plus sub-freezing temps all day raises black-ice risk on bridges/overpasses, untreated neighborhood streets, and parking lots.
Visibility is the biggest wild card: multiple hours overnight show very low/0 mi visibility. If that is real dense fog/low stratus at 6–8 AM, bus operations become higher-risk even without snow.

Temperatures/wind chills are cold (teens with wind chills near/under 0°F at times), but not in the “automatic closure” range; more likely to prompt exposure mitigations (limit outdoor time, ensure bus-stop coverage) than cancel school.
Road crews likely improve trunklines/primary routes by morning; residual slickness is more likely on secondary/local streets and school grounds (drop-off loops, sidewalks).

positions.rationale:
As the NEWS specialist, I weight (a) official closure announcements and (b) regional “domino” patterns heavily, because they often reflect what decision-makers are actually preparing to do. Here, those signals are limited for Monday 2026-01-26: no Rockford announcement was found, and the only clear nearby closure referenced is Sparta on Friday 2026-01-23.

The weather story for Monday is not a classic closure setup (no accumulating snow, modest winds). The plausible news-style trigger is a Monday-morning “black ice + dense fog” commute problem, but that tends to produce delays rather than district-wide closure unless it’s widespread and verified on major corridors.

Net: I put the snow-day probability in the high-teens—non-trivial due to fog/ice timing and recent regional travel hazards, but still more likely than not that schools run (possibly with extra cautions or a delay).
keyFactors: Official/"domino" signals are weak: no Rockford Public Schools notice for Mon 2026-01-26 in the scan; nearby districts referenced (e.g., Sparta) showed a closure for Fri 2026-01-23 but not a clear Mon closure wave.

Forecast for Mon 2026-01-26 shows essentially *no new snow accumulation* (0 cm) and near-zero QPF; this usually suppresses district-wide closures in West Michigan absent major ice or blizzard visibility.

The most news-relevant operational risk is *travel safety optics* after recent severe conditions in the region (e.g., earlier I-196 pileup / whiteout messaging). That context can make districts more cautious, but it’s not determinative without a fresh Monday-morning hazard.

Potential “headline” hazards for Monday morning are *patchy black ice* from light freezing rain around 12:00 AM and *very low visibility* (fog/low stratus indicated by several hours with near-zero vis). Those are more consistent with delays/limited route adjustments than a full closure, unless they verify widespread at 5–7 AM.
Power-grid/outage story does not support closure: outages appear isolated; no broad utility disruption signal.

positions.rationale: I’m moving sharply down from the prior meteorology position (88%) because the forecast does **not** support a snow-driven closure: Monday shows essentially **no accumulating snow** and negligible QPF. The only credible closure pathway is a *compound* scenario: patchy overnight glaze + genuinely dense fog at bus time causing unsafe travel on secondary roads. That’s a real risk, but historically it produces delays more often than full closures. Net: low-but-nontrivial probability.
keyFactors: Near-zero *new* wintry precip on Monday itself: total precip ~0.01 mm, forecast snow total 0 cm, daily snow chance only 4% → very weak “classic snow day” signal.

Main hazard is *surface icing/black ice*, not accumulation: brief light freezing rain/drizzle signal around 00:00 Monday with temps ~11°F, then temps stay below freezing all day so any glaze won’t melt.

Visibility is the biggest wild card: multiple overnight/early-morning hours show 0 mi (and 1 mi) visibility, consistent with dense fog/freezing fog or very low stratus. If that verifies during the 6–8 AM bus window, it can trigger a delay/closure even without snow.
Winds are only modest (sustained ~10–15 mph; gusts ~20–25 mph). Wind chill gets uncomfortable (down near ~-5°F late day) but not typically an automatic closure driver for West Michigan.
Timing: worst impacts cluster before dawn (icing + potential dense fog). By late morning, visibility/roads likely improve enough for normal operations unless there’s a true widespread glaze event.

positions.rationale:
As the HISTORY specialist, I’m anchoring on how districts in the Rockford/greater Grand Rapids area typically make decisions in late January. Monday, January 26, 2026 has the “post-event, cold but quiet” signature: no meaningful new snow and only trace precip indicated. In comparable past setups, districts overwhelmingly stay open, sometimes with heightened caution.

I am *raising* my prior 12% slightly to 14% after considering peers: (1) Safety’s emphasis on refreeze/black ice risk is plausible given Sunday’s wintry mix and sub-freezing temps all day Monday; and (2) Meteorology’s identification of a potential dense-fog window (very low vis values) increases the chance of a disruption decision if it coincides with bus routes. Even so, without confirmed widespread icing or heavy snow rates during the commute, a full snow day remains more likely than not to be avoided.
keyFactors: Historical behavior in West Michigan/Kent County: a cold, mostly dry day with highs in the teens and no accumulating snow is typically a normal “schools open” day; closures usually require heavy snow during the AM commute, widespread glaze ice, or true whiteout/blizzard visibility.
Forecast for Monday 2026-01-26 shows essentially no new accumulation (0 cm snow; ~0.01 mm precip). That strongly suppresses classic closure probability.

Main historical “gotcha” pathway is *residual* impacts from Sunday’s wintry mix plus a brief overnight freezing-rain/drizzle signal near 12:00 AM Monday—patchy black ice can persist on untreated secondary roads/bridges into bus time when temps stay ~10–12°F.

The repeated near-zero visibility values overnight/early morning could indicate dense fog/low stratus. Historically, fog alone rarely closes; fog + patchy ice can sometimes push districts toward a delay/closure if it lines up with 6–8 AM bus runs.

Institutional/operational inertia: after a Sunday event, road agencies often pre-treat and clean up ahead of Monday, which historically reduces full-closure odds unless a new hazard develops right before daybreak.

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint for Monday 2026-01-26 in Rockford, MI, I’m slightly lowering my prior 18% to 16% because the forecast precipitation on Monday is essentially negligible and the icing signal is very low-QPF and concentrated near midnight rather than during the core 6–8 AM bus window. That said, I won’t go as low as the history agent’s ~12% because the dataset’s near-zero visibility hours are a meaningful operational hazard if they’re real (dense fog/low stratus), and the combination of cold + refreeze can create high-consequence patchy black ice on secondary roads. Net: more likely than not schools operate, but with a non-trivial chance of a delay or (less likely) closure if early-morning road checks/visibility are worse than expected.
keyFactors: No accumulating snow forecast for Monday (0 cm / ~0"), which strongly reduces the classic ‘impassable roads’ closure pathway.

Temps stay well below freezing all day (~10–17°F). Any moisture from Sunday’s wintry mix and the brief ‘light freezing rain’ signal around 12:00 AM Monday can freeze in place → patchy black ice risk, especially on bridges/overpasses/untreated neighborhood streets.

Visibility is the biggest safety wildcard: multiple hours show 0–1 mile (and even 0) visibility overnight into early morning. If that’s real dense fog/low stratus coinciding with bus runs, it can push a marginal “open” day toward delay/closure for transportation safety.

Wind is moderate (sustained ~10–15 mph, gusts ~20–25 mph) and can worsen wind chills (near/under 0°F at times), increasing bus-stop exposure risk; however, cold alone here usually drives ‘precautionary ops’ more than a full closure unless wind chills are extreme.

Infrastructure/plowing context suggests main routes likely improve by pre-dawn, but local/residential connectors and parking lots can remain slick—this supports ‘delays/caution’ more than a district-wide cancel.

positions.rationale:
From a NEWS/decision-signals lens, closures correlate most with (1) official district comms and (2) neighboring-district “domino” patterns—both are currently weak for Monday 2026-01-26. The weather data also doesn’t support a snow-accumulation closure.

The only realistic pathway to a snow day is a late-breaking, widely verified Monday-morning safety issue (black ice + dense fog) that gets picked up by local authorities/media and reflected in widespread delays/closures. Given the extremely low precip totals, I think the more likely outcome is **open** (possibly with heightened caution or a delay), so I’m slightly below my prior 18% and land at **16%**.
keyFactors: **No current “domino” closure signal for Monday 2026-01-26**: In the info provided, Rockford Public Schools has no Monday closure/delay post, and nearby districts don’t show Monday closures either (Sparta closure was for Fri 01/23/26). That usually implies “planning to open” unless conditions worsen overnight.

**Forecast isn’t a classic snow-day setup**: zero forecast snow accumulation (totalsnow_cm = 0) and near-zero QPF on Monday strongly reduces the odds of a district-wide closure versus a normal cold-weather school day.

**But there is a credible *commute-disruption* narrative**: brief light freezing rain at 12:00 AM Monday + sustained subfreezing temps means any untreated/wet surfaces could become slick (black-ice risk). This is the main “news-type” trigger that can flip decisions late Sunday night/early Monday.

**Visibility red flags in the hourly feed**: multiple hours showing 0–1 mile and even 0 mi visibility overnight into early morning (roughly 1–8 AM). If real (dense fog/low stratus), that can push districts toward *delay* decisions; full closure is less common but possible if it’s widespread and coincides with bus start times.

**Recent regional travel hazards raise sensitivity**: earlier week high-impact crashes/whiteout messaging in the broader Grand Rapids area suggests decision-makers may be more risk-averse; still, without a Monday warning/advisory aimed at Kent County, it’s only a modest upward pressure.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 24 at 2:30PM EST until January 25 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...Along the Muskegon River in Newaygo County, downriver of
Croton Dam, around the city of Newaygo and toward Bridgeton

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Low lying areas along the Muskegon River that are prone
to flooding may see rapidly changing water levels.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 215 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Saturday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. Flooding due
to freeze-up ice jams is typically minor, but can be
unpredictable.
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 25 at 3:27AM EST until January 25 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations between 1 and 3 inches.

* WHERE...Barry County.

* WHEN...Until 10 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
alert.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling.
